Quel piccolo insediamento può contribuire poco allo sforzo per sconfiggere il Culto del Drago, tuttavia, e in verità, Isteval è stato arruolato dal Cormyr per ottenere informazioni su quella che sembra essere una guerra che si sta preparando sul suo confine occidentale.

Isteval ha troppo rispetto per gli altri delegati per nascondere loro questa informazione, e assicura ai presenti che la sua lealtà a Daggerford, a Cormyr, all'Alleanza dei Lord e a tutta la brava gente non è in contrasto. Questo approccio schietto provoca tuttavia un tumulto tra gli altri delegati, e gli avventurieri devono intervenire per assicurarsi che Isteval non venga espulso dalle riunioni del consiglio.

Veterano dell'uccisione dei draghi, Isteval porta una ferita alla gamba che resiste alla guarigione magica e cammina con un bastone fatto con un osso del drago verde che gli ha inflitto la ferita. Il paladino può essere un'utile fonte di conoscenze sui draghi, ma i suoi consigli sono sempre prudenti. Vede la sua infermità come un promemoria del suo dio Lathander sui pericoli dell'arroganza. Come si addice all'etica della sua divinità, Isteval ha scelto di trattare la sua ferita come un motivo per incoraggiare l'eroismo degli altri, anche se la sua stessa leggenda sta svanendo. Tuttavia, in momenti come questi, quando il mondo ha bisogno di eroi, non gli piace che gli si ricordi che deve guardare la lotta da bordo campo.

Isteval crede negli eroi come la scintilla che può accendere le fiamme della rettitudine negli altri e la luce che scaccia le tenebre del male. Vedere questa scintilla negli avventurieri rende il paladino uno dei più forti sostenitori del partito al Consiglio di Waterdeep, a patto che segua un percorso di principi.

Sir Isteval ha molto in comune con {@creature Ontharr Frume|HotDQ} dell'Ordine del Guanto. I due sono potenziali alleati in tutto e per tutto, il che preoccupa alcuni degli altri membri dell'Alleanza dei Signori.

entries.name: The Zhentarim
entries: Gli Zhentarim, noti anche come la Rete Nera, sono un'associazione di mercanti, mercenari e malfattori. La gente comune conosce gli Zhentarim come le persone a cui rivolgersi quando si ha bisogno delle migliori guardie o mercenari che il denaro possa comprare. E se il carico è losco o la causa per cui stai combattendo è discutibile o addirittura ingiusta, agli Zhentarim non importa.

L'affiliazione con gli Zhentarim può essere vantaggiosa per venditori, ladri e furfanti di ogni tipo. È plausibile che gli avventurieri della tua campagna possano diventare membri dell'organizzazione, ma come la maggior parte degli abitanti di Faerûn, non conosceranno l'intera portata delle operazioni e degli obiettivi degli Zhentarim.

Sconosciuto a tutti tranne che a pochi, il cuore degli Zhentarim è una cabala di capi malvagi e a volte mostruosi che cercano di estendere la portata della Rete Nera intrisa di sangue in ogni assassinio, mercato nero e affare illegale che avviene a Faerûn. Le connessioni criminali dell'ordine penetrano in ogni grande città e gilda di ladri nelle Heartlands occidentali e lungo la Costa della Spada. Ovunque la moneta di una città sia disastrosamente minata dalla contraffazione, ovunque un'impresa emergente abbia la meglio sulla concorrenza, e ovunque una lotta politica si trasformi in un'intimidazione diffusa, è sicuro che gli Zhentarim siano coinvolti.

Tuttavia, impegnarsi nella corruzione tradizionale e voler vedere Tiamat ascendere sono due cose diverse. Gli Zhentarim non si fanno illusioni su cosa significherebbe il ritorno della Regina dei Draghi per i loro piani. Volendo governare segretamente il mondo dall'ombra per se stessi, i leader della Rete Nera non hanno alcun desiderio di diventare agenti e galoppini per qualche dio meschino e le sue coorti di draghi.

Questo punto di vista rende gli Zhentarim un'interessante aggiunta ai possibili alleati dei personaggi. In circostanze normali, gli Arpisti, l'Alleanza dei Signori, l'Ordine del Guanto e l'Enclave di Smeraldo eviterebbero i legami con la Rete Nera ed eventualmente arresterebbero i suoi emissari. Tuttavia, la crisi creata dal Culto del Drago è senza precedenti. Ogni risorsa che può essere radunata sarà necessaria nella resa dei conti finale contro il culto, e la rete di spie, assassini ed eserciti mercenari degli Zhentarim non può essere ignorata.

Anche se il destino del mondo e il futuro stesso degli Zhentarim sono in bilico, l'ordine esige un pagamento per i suoi servizi, e dove il bisogno e il rischio sono maggiori, ci si aspetta che la paga sia altrettanto grande. Questo atteggiamento mercenario non piace all'Alleanza dei Signori, tuttavia, e loro sono l'unico gruppo con le risorse per pagare il prezzo della Rete Nera. Gli eroi possono tentare di influenzare le opinioni delle altre fazioni e hanno la possibilità di comprare la fedeltà degli Zhentarim nel seguito di {@adventure chapter 15|RoT|6}.

Alla fine, la posta in gioco è troppo alta per rimanere seduti in questa battaglia, e gli Zhentarim scendono in campo contro il culto indipendentemente dal fatto che il loro prezzo sia pagato. Tuttavia, se le altre fazioni vogliono avere voce in capitolo su come gli Zhentarim entrano in guerra contro il culto, questo costerà loro. Se gli Zhentarim combattono da soli, colpiscono quando e come vogliono.

Almeno una missione della Rete Nera viene portata a termine indipendentemente dal pagamento. All'insaputa di chiunque al di fuori degli Zhentarim, uno dei loro agenti si è infiltrato nel culto e si avvicina abbastanza al Wyrmspeaker Varram per rubare il {@i White Dragon Mask}. Questo furto mette in moto una sequenza di eventi che culmina nella parte di Varram del capitolo "{@adventure Death to the Wyrmspeakers|RoT|3}".

entries.name: Using the Zhentarim
entries: Gli agenti della Rete Nera sono utili PNG che puoi introdurre in momenti appropriati dell'avventura. I personaggi che hanno giocato {@i Hoard of the Dragon Queen} hanno già incontrato un membro della Rete Nera: lo gnomo femmina {@creature Jamna Gleamsilver|HotDQ}. Se i personaggi hanno bisogno di informazioni o attrezzature che non possono ottenere in altro modo, cercare o essere avvicinati da un agente Zhentarim è un modo semplice per fornirle.

Un tipico agente della Rete Nera è un avventuriero molto capace e senza scrupoli. Alcuni Zhentarim hanno compagni serpenti alati che portano messaggi su pergamene mentre volano, permettendo agli agenti di tenersi in contatto tra loro.

Anche se gli Zhentarim nel loro insieme si oppongono ai piani del culto, non tutti nella Rete Nera condividono questa opinione. Alcuni agenti Zhentarim credono che la vittoria del culto sia inevitabile e che, opponendosi al culto, gli Zhentarim rischiano di perdere tutto. Se gli eventi stanno andando troppo lisci per gli eroi, puoi introdurre qualche agente della Rete Nera che metta i bastoni tra le ruote ai piani dei personaggi nel peggior momento possibile.

entries.name: Rian Nightshade
entries: {@i Lawful evil female tiefling warlock}
{@b Ideals}: Logica, avidità ("Sono certo che possiamo giungere ad un accordo che tutte le parti favoriranno. Ma in caso contrario, abbiamo altri mezzi per risolvere la questione").
{@b Interaction Traits}: Educato, mercantile, spietato
{@b Pledged Resources}: Assassini e mercenari

Rian è un membro degli Zhentarim e l'inviato della Rete Nera durante il terzo Consiglio di Waterdeep. È seduta al tavolo come consigliere speciale di Lord Neverember, e la sua affiliazione con gli Zhentarim non sarà menzionata. Tuttavia, né lei né Lord Neverember cercano di negare o nascondere tale affiliazione se i personaggi si chiedono perché Rian sia presente.

La Rete Nera appoggia qualsiasi piano che aumenti la probabilità di sconfiggere il culto. Qualsiasi alleanza va bene, così come qualsiasi risultato che aumenti le risorse strategiche del consiglio. Rian non ha un particolare interesse per la moralità, e gli atti oscuri non hanno alcun impatto sul suo atteggiamento verso il partito. Tuttavia, disapprova il fatto di prendere vivo qualsiasi wyrmspeaker, temendo il potere di tali figure pericolose e mettendo in dubbio le possibilità di successo dei tentativi di trasformarli o interrogarli. Preferisce un'esecuzione discreta, l'interrogatorio del cadavere con rituali appropriati e la distruzione del corpo per evitare la resurrezione.

La Rete Nera rimane senza impegno fino al consiglio finale, quando vengono presi gli impegni. Se il gruppo si è guadagnato il rispetto degli Zhentarim, essi forniscono i loro servizi ad un costo nominale. Tuttavia, tale azione quasi certamente allontana la maggior parte delle altre fazioni dagli avventurieri. A differenza delle altre fazioni, la lealtà degli Zhentarim può essere acquistata indipendentemente dal loro rispetto per i personaggi, se il party può negoziare i termini per essere pagato dalle altre fazioni.

entries.name: Metallic Dragons
entries: I draghi buoni di Faerûn sentono il richiamo {@i Draakhorn's} e sanno cosa porta. Con il destino del mondo in bilico, i draghi buoni agiranno per opporsi al ritorno di Tiamat. Tuttavia, resta da vedere se lo faranno di concerto con le fazioni umanoidi della Costa della Spada, o se colpiranno da soli senza pensare o preoccuparsi del destino delle razze inferiori.

entries.name: Using Metallic Dragons
entries: I draghi metallici colpiranno i cultisti al Pozzo dei Draghi, ma sono molto più efficaci se i loro attacchi sono coordinati come parte del piano generale di battaglia. Inoltre, se possono essere portati nell'alleanza rappresentata dal Consiglio di Waterdeep, possono aiutare a difendere i territori umanoidi dalle devastanti incursioni del culto. Questo è trattato più in dettaglio in {@adventure chapter 14|RoT|5}.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Anche se molti giganti si sono uniti al Culto del Drago, la maggior parte ricorda le antiche guerre tra draghi e giganti con amarezza e odio. I racconti di faide, salassi e morte alimentano l'odio dei giganti verso i draghi, ma le razze giganti sono padroni di se stesse. Come tali, non collaborano facilmente con le piccole razze. Anche quando i giganti buoni vedono la necessità e la saggezza di unire le forze con la gente minore, spesso resistono all'idea per orgoglio fino a quando qualcuno o qualcosa non riesce a comandare il loro rispetto.

entries.name: Using Giants
entries: Impegnare i giganti in un'alleanza contro il Culto del Drago può essere gestito dai PNG (molto probabilmente dai membri degli Harper o dell'Enclave di Smeraldo). Se i personaggi hanno completato {@i Hoard of the Dragon Queen} il possesso del Castello di Skyreach, offrire di restituirlo ai giganti (o dietro le quinte o in un capitolo di trekking secondario di tua creazione) è sicuro di garantire il loro sostegno alle fazioni contro il Culto del Drago. La presenza dei giganti alla resa dei conti finale sarà un enorme vantaggio per le forze che combattono contro il culto.

data.name: Chapter 1: Greenest in Flames
entries: La città di Greenest fu fondata dalla halfling Dharva Scatterheart, una canaglia che si credeva la regina dei Greenfields. Scatterheart è morta senza mai raggiungere quel livello di eminenza, ma la sua città è cresciuta in una comunità fiorente. Il suo successo non è sorprendente, dato che Greenest è l'unica città di qualsiasi dimensione a cavallo del Sentiero Uldoon, la strada più diretta tra le città orientali della Costa del Drago, Cormyr e Sembia e la Via della Costa che corre verso sud fino alle grandi città di Amn, Tethyr e il lontano Calimshan. Le carovane commerciali che passano per Greenest portano oro ai mercanti e agli artigiani della città, e il governatore Nighthill gestisce la città per volere degli abitanti.

Gli avventurieri potrebbero essere in viaggio da una città all'altra o tornare alle loro case dopo un viaggio lontano. In alternativa, potrebbero accompagnare un mercante o un ricco viaggiatore come guardie del corpo. Molti giovani irrequieti di Faerûn hanno avuto il loro primo assaggio di viaggio e avventura come guardie di carovana.

Si può adattare {@i Tyranny of Dragons} a diverse regioni dei Regni o a un'ambientazione diversa con un po' più di preparazione da parte vostra. Cambiate i nomi e i luoghi per adattarli alla vostra campagna.

entries.name: Character Hooks
entries: Per legare più strettamente le storie dei personaggi alla campagna {@i Tyranny of Dragons}, vedi {@adventure appendix A|HotDQ|9}.

entries.name: The Approach
entries: Quando i personaggi si avvicinano a Greenest, vedono che un drago blu e i suoi alleati del Culto del Drago stanno attaccando la città. I cultisti cercano di raccogliere un tesoro che sperano di presentare a Tiamat al suo arrivo nel mondo. Il culto ha messo insieme una forza potente per questa incursione, riunendo banditi, kobold, mercenari e altri tipi di mercenari in un piccolo esercito. Anche un monaco di nome {@creature Leosin Erlanthar|HotDQ} era in città. Attraverso una diligente ricerca e interviste condotte durante i suoi viaggi tra Berdusk e Candlekeep, Leosin si è convinto che il culto è impegnato in una grande operazione, ma non sa ancora di cosa si tratta. Leosin usa l'incursione come un'opportunità per infiltrarsi nel culto in modo da poterne conoscere meglio i piani. Viene però scoperto e catturato, e ha bisogno dell'aiuto dei personaggi per fuggire dalla prigionia.
I personaggi possono impegnarsi in diversi incontri mentre cultisti e kobold imperversano per Greenest.

Negli ultimi giorni, hai viaggiato su una strada che si snoda pigramente attraverso i prati ondulati dei Greenfields. Il tramonto si sta avvicinando quando, in cima a un'altura, vedi la città di Greenest a pochi chilometri di distanza. Ma invece della città piacevole e accogliente che ti aspettavi, vedi colonne di fumo nero che si alzano da edifici in fiamme, figure in corsa che sono poco più che punti a questa distanza e una forma scura e alata che ruota bassa sopra il torrione che si erge sopra il centro della città. Greenest è stato attaccato da un drago!

La sequenza degli eventi che seguono dipende da voi e dai personaggi. Puoi presentare loro tutti gli incontri che vuoi, in qualsiasi ordine. L'unica eccezione è "{@area Seek the Keep|070|x}", che dovrebbe essere il primo incontro dopo che i personaggi entrano nel Greenest.

entries.name: General Features
entries: Il sole è già tramontato quando i personaggi raggiungono la periferia della città (l'area indicata sulla mappa di Greenest).

entries.name: Light
entries: Edifici in fiamme e una mezza luna forniscono una luce fioca in tutta la città. L'interno del torrione è brillantemente illuminato.

entries.name: Fires
entries: I cultisti hanno cercato di incendiare gli edifici mentre attraversavano la città, ma la paglia non è così infiammabile come sembra. Quando i personaggi arrivano, la maggior parte delle fiamme proviene da pagliai e fienili, non da case o negozi.

entries.name: The Stream
entries: Il ruscello che scorre oltre Greenest è poco profondo (raramente più di 3 piedi di profondità) con un fondo di ghiaia, quindi i personaggi possono muoversi lungo di esso senza difficoltà. Dove le sponde sono chiare, il ruscello è facile da entrare o uscire. La vegetazione vicino al torrente è densa e le rive sono ripide dove la vegetazione cresce. I personaggi possono muoversi solo di 5 piedi per turno attraverso la boscaglia.

entries.name: Governor Nighthill
entries: L'uomo che gestisce Greenest è Tarbaw Nighthill, un maschio umano di sessant'anni. Se i personaggi chiedono chi comanda, vengono indirizzati a Nighthill. Sta camminando in cima al parapetto della fortezza quando il cielo è sereno, o all'interno della fortezza se il drago sta attaccando. Se i personaggi non cercano il governatore quando raggiungono la fortezza, sarà lui a trovarli. In entrambi i casi, Nighthill li accoglie e li porta sul parapetto. Da lì, hanno la migliore vista di Greenest.

Il lato destro del viso e la testa di Nighthill sono bendati, il suo braccio destro pende in una fascia e la sua tunica azzurra è macchiata del suo stesso sangue. Ha ricevuto queste ferite durante le prime fasi dell'attacco e non ha risparmiato il tempo per un primo soccorso più che sommario.

entries.name: Castellan Escobert the Red
entries: Escobert è un nano da scudo con capelli annodati, aggrovigliati e di colore rosso vivo. Come padrone del mastio, Escobert è responsabile della sua difesa ed è la migliore fonte di informazioni sul tunnel e sulla porta d'ingresso (vedi "{@area The Old Tunnel|074|x}" e "{@area The Sally Port|078|x}" di seguito). Porta con sé un enorme anello di chiavi di ferro e ottone per le numerose serrature del torrione.

entries.name: Wandering Encounters
entries: Le strade di Greenest sono invase da forze composte da {@creature Cultist||cultists} e {@creature Acolyte||acolytes} accompagnate da mostruosi alleati: {@creature Kobold||kobolds} con {@creature Ambush Drake|HotDQ|ambush drakes} (vedi {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}) e {@creature Giant Lizard||giant lizards}. Questi razziatori si muovono attraverso la città senza paura, saccheggiando al loro passaggio. Mentre i personaggi viaggiano attraverso il villaggio assediato, possono imbattersi nei razziatori e negli abitanti della città. Usa queste linee guida per determinare se i personaggi hanno un incontro.

Se i personaggi usano la copertura e la furtività per evitare gli incontri, fai fare ad ogni personaggio una prova di Destrezza ({@skill Stealth}) a dc 10. Per ogni due prove individuali che falliscono, i personaggi hanno un incontro sulla strada verso la loro destinazione. Tira un {@dice d8} sulla tabella degli Incontri del Capitolo 1 per determinare ogni incontro. Se i personaggi usano il letto del ruscello come copertura per la maggior parte del viaggio, questi personaggi hanno un vantaggio sulle loro prove di Destrezza.

Se i personaggi non usano copertura e furtività per evitare gli incontri, tira un {@dice d8} per ogni 100 piedi che muovono in città. Se il risultato è 4 o inferiore, non hanno attirato l'attenzione con quel movimento. Se il tiro è 5 o più alto, si imbattono in qualcosa; tira di nuovo un {@dice d8} e controlla la tabella degli Incontri del Capitolo 1 per vedere cosa incontrano i personaggi.

entries.name: Chapter 1 Encounters

rows: 3 {@creature Kobold||kobolds} e 1 {@creature ambush drake|HotDQ} (vedi {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12})
{@dice 1d6} abitanti della città braccati dai razziatori (tira un {@dice d6} per determinare il gruppo di razziatori)

entries: * Gli accoliti hanno preparato {@spell command} invece di {@spell sanctuary}.
La maggior parte dei cultisti, delle guardie e degli accoliti sono umani. È possibile includere alcuni nani, mezz'elfi, mezz'orchi o halfling senza alterare le statistiche di gioco.

entries.name: Stolen Treasure
entries: I cultisti e i loro lacchè kobold stanno saccheggiando Greenest e raccogliendo il bottino per trasportarlo al loro accampamento (vedi {@adventure chapter 2|HotDQ|2}). Ogni gruppo di predoni che il gruppo incontra ha una probabilità del {@chance 50|50 percent} di essere in possesso di un tesoro rubato. Tira un {@dice d6} e moltiplica il risultato per 10 per determinare il valore totale degli oggetti rubati, in pezzi d'oro (gp).

entries.name: Seek the Keep
entries: I personaggi hanno incontri casuali con i razziatori quando entrano nel Greenest, ma questa dovrebbe essere la loro prima missione del capitolo. Inizia quando una famiglia umana terrorizzata (padre, madre e tre bambini piccoli) si precipita sul loro cammino, braccata da Seven {@creature Kobold||kobolds}.

Senza preavviso, cinque umani sbucano da due edifici alla tua sinistra. Un uomo zoppicante e tre bambini piccoli corrono dall'altra parte della strada verso altre ombre, e una donna che porta uno scudo rotondo e una lancia spezzata si gira e torna indietro nella direzione da cui sono venuti. Otto gobold escono dal vicolo alle calcagna della famiglia e si dispongono a ventaglio intorno alla donna, che sembra determinata a ritardare le creature il più a lungo possibile.

La donna è {@creature Linan Swift|HotDQ} e suo marito è Cuth. Linan è un {@creature commoner} ma con 8 punti ferita. Il suo attacco con la lancia è +2 a colpire per {@dice 1d6} danni perforanti. Suo marito è sceso a 2 punti ferita da un combattimento precedente. I bambini si muovono a velocità 20. Possono essere trasportati, ma un personaggio che trasporta un bambino ha svantaggio nei tiri di attacco e non può brandire un'arma a due mani.

A meno che i personaggi non intervengano, i goblin presumono che i personaggi siano dei cultisti e li ignorano. Supponendo che i personaggi intervengano e salvino la famiglia, Linan spiega che devono dirigersi verso la fortezza (nell'area 1); è l'unico posto sicuro a Greenest. I razziatori non hanno allestito un cordone efficace intorno al torrione, quindi è ancora possibile muoversi attraverso il cancello anteriore, ma non per molto.

Per raggiungere il mastio, i personaggi devono superare tre gruppi di razziatori. Un gruppo è composto da {@dice 1d6} {@creature Kobold||kobolds} e {@dice 1d4} {@creature Cultist||cultists}. Se il gruppo contiene sei kobold, uno è un {@creature Winged Kobold||winged kobold (urd)}.

I personaggi possono combattere questi nemici, superarli di nascosto, ritirarsi per evitarli del tutto, o provare qualcosa di intelligente come il bluff. Se combattono, eseguono il combattimento normalmente. Quando i nemici devono fare una prova per accorgersi di sgattaiolare o bluffare, fare una prova con vantaggio per il gruppo.

Ogni volta che i personaggi si ritirano da un gruppo nemico per evitarlo, si imbattono in {@dice 1d6} altri cittadini che stanno cercando di raggiungere il torrione. Per ogni quattro abitanti in più al seguito, il gruppo deve superare un gruppo nemico in più per raggiungere la fortezza.

Al mastio, i personaggi sono l'ultimo gruppo che attraversa il cancello prima che venga chiuso e sbarrato. Dopo che i personaggi entrano nella fortezza, i razziatori la circondano in numero crescente.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Oltre a guadagnare punti esperienza (XP) per i razziatori combattuti sulla strada per il mastio, i personaggi guadagnano un bonus di 50 XP per ogni personaggio non giocante (PNG) portato vivo nel mastio. Dividi equamente questo bonus tra i membri del gruppo. In alternativa, se stai usando la regola dell'esperienza miliare, i personaggi raggiungono il 2° livello una volta arrivati al mastio.

entries.name: Missions
entries: Gli eventi in Greenest sono divisi in missioni. Le missioni non devono necessariamente comportare un combattimento, ma la maggior parte lo fa.
I personaggi raggiungono la città al tramonto, ovvero verso le 21. Il sole sorge di nuovo alle 6 del mattino successivo, ma gli ultimi razziatori se ne sono andati entro le 4 del mattino.

Per ragioni di tempo, supponiamo che ogni missione duri un'ora. Il tempo durante l'ora che non viene speso per combattere o sgattaiolare attraverso la città viene speso per curare l'equipaggiamento, fasciare le ferite minori, pattugliare le mura della fortezza, informare Nighthill sulla situazione e altri compiti banali. Se i personaggi prendono un breve riposo, non possono intraprendere nessun'altra missione in quell'ora.

Se i giocatori hanno bisogno di una guida, il governatore Nighthill può dare ai personaggi un rapido briefing sulla situazione tattica. I predoni hanno isolato il torrione dalla città con gruppi di guardie che lo circondano, ma non hanno organizzato un attacco. Nighthill pensa che i razziatori non abbiano intenzione di attaccare il torrione; sembrano interessati solo al bottino. Il vero pericolo è per la città e per le persone che non sono riuscite ad entrare nella fortezza prima che fosse tagliata fuori. Nighthill vuole che i personaggi rientrino nella città e aiutino le persone rimaste tagliate fuori o molestino i razziatori. Un gruppo furtivo può uscire dalla fortezza e rientrare senza attirare l'attenzione dei razziatori.

entries.name: The Old Tunnel
entries: Uno stretto tunnel corre dalla cantina sotto il mastio fino alla riva del torrente (area 2). Il tunnel è abbastanza largo da permettere ai guerrieri di attraversarlo in fila indiana. Nel torrione, il tunnel è sigillato con una porta di ferro chiusa a chiave, e l'uscita del torrente è coperta da una grata di ferro chiusa a chiave che sembra un'uscita della fogna. La funzione principale del tunnel era un mezzo segreto per raccogliere l'acqua dal torrente durante un assedio, ma può essere usato anche come porta d'ingresso. Poiché il torrione non è mai stato assediato, il vecchio tunnel non è mai stato usato. Barili e casse sono ammassati davanti alla porta. Le chiavi delle serrature sono sull'anello che Escobert porta con sé ovunque.
A un certo punto, Escobert raccomanda il tunnel come mezzo per far entrare di nascosto i cittadini nella fortezza senza correre il guanto di sfida degli assalitori che sorvegliano le porte.

entries.name: Locks
entries: I personaggi possono liberare la porta della cantina con qualche minuto di lavoro. La serratura è rigida ma si apre con la chiave; senza la chiave, il personaggio può aprire la serratura con una prova di Destrezza DC 10 riuscita e un set di {@item thieves' tools|PHB}. Il tunnel in disuso è soffocato da ragnatele, ma per il resto è libero. A pochi metri all'interno della fine del torrente c'è un nido di due {@creature Swarm of Rats||swarms of rats}. I ratti attaccano quando vengono disturbati, e i ratti sopravvissuti fuggono quando metà del loro numero muore.

Years of exposure and neglect have corroded the lock on the exit grate. Even with the key, a successful DC 10 Dexterity check is needed to open the lock. Without the key, the DC increases to 20. If the roll misses by 5 or more, the key or {@item thieves' tools|PHB} break off in the lock so that unlocking it becomes impossible. Then only a successful DC 15 Strength check can force the grate open.

entries.name: Foes
entries: A group of cultists is searching the stream banks for hiding townsfolk when the characters emerge from the tunnel. If characters open the lock with the key or with {@item thieves' tools|PHB}, the first one to exit notices the raiders approaching without being spotted in return; the characters can keep out of sight in the tunnel or try to ambush the raiders after they pass. If the check fails, the raiders spot the character; roll initiative and proceed with combat. If the grate had to be broken open with a Strength check, the raiders hear the noise and find cover; they wait for the characters to exit the tunnel, then gain a surprise round. The raiders' group consists of two {@creature Cultist||cultists} and six {@creature Kobold||kobolds}. If any cultists are still alive at the beginning of the fourth round of the fight, one of them runs to fetch help. Ten minutes later, two {@creature Cultist||cultists}, ten {@creature Kobold||kobolds}, and one {@creature ambush drake|HotDQ} (see {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}) arrive to guard the tunnel.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Award standard XP for defeated foes. Aside from that, the chief reward for this mission is the tunnel itself. As long as it remains secret, characters can use it to enter and exit the keep safely. Each time they use the tunnel exit, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 1, raiders see and attack the characters (use the {@area Chapter 1 Encounters|06e|x} table). On a 2, they are seen but not attacked. Instead, the raiders set an ambush and attack the next time the characters return to the tunnel exit.

entries.name: The Sally Port
entries: The keep has a sally port along the west wall for counterattacking foes who bring a battering ram against the gates. During the night while characters are in the keep, raiders approach the old gate, force it open, and rush through. Escobert discovers them and races into the courtyard to sound the alarm ahead of the infiltrators.

Enough defenders are available to deal with the immediate threat from raiders loose in the keep, since it's more a probe that got out of hand rather than a full-scale assault. Escobert is most concerned about resealing the sally port, and he seeks out the characters for that job.

To secure the sally port, characters must battle through two groups of foes. The first fight occurs against three {@creature Acolyte||acolytes}, three {@creature Kobold||kobolds}, and one {@creature ambush drake|HotDQ} (see {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}), which are guarding the sally port's 10-foot-by-20-foot ready room against exactly this type of counterattack. After characters seize the room, they discover that the door is heavily damaged. The fastest repair is with five castings of {@spell mending} (taking five minutes). If none of the characters can do this, an NPC in the keep knows the cantrip. Someone must find and fetch her to the ready room.

Before the door can be repaired, a second group of raiders consisting of two {@creature Guard||guards}, three {@creature Cultist||cultists}, and three {@creature Kobold||kobolds} attacks. These foes can come from outside the keep, or they might be a group of infiltrators trying to fight its way back outside. If characters barricade the door with barrels or other heavy objects while awaiting repairs, they might hold off attackers until the repairs are finished and avoid this fight entirely.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Award standard XP for defeated foes.

entries.name: Dragon Attack
entries: The {@creature adult blue dragon} Lennithon accompanied this raid but is not an enthusiastic participant. Its chief contribution has been its Frightful Presence, but that becomes less effective as the night wears on and defenders overcome their fear. Shortly before midnight, the dragon launches a final assault against the citadel. {@creature Frulam Mondath|HotDQ} orders the attack, knowing that the adventurers are in the keep at the time. Lennithon doesn't consider this to be its fight, and it isn't keen on tangling with adventurers for another's benefit.

During this attack, Lennithon flies over the keep and uses his breath weapon without moving closer than 25 feet from the parapet. The defenders on the walls have mastered their fear of the dragon's Frightful Presence from earlier attacks. There are twenty NPC defenders on the walls at the beginning of the mission, and more can arrive between attacks to take the place of those who fall. The dragon doesn't target the adventures at first, and every breath attack not directed at them kills {@dice 1d4} NPC defenders and injures {@dice 1d6} more. Adventurers who happen to get caught in the area make normal saving throws and take standard damage. The NPCs' attacks are ineffective against Lennithon. Bear in mind that the dragon's breath weapon will kill a 1st-level character outright, so be sure to demonstrate its destructive power to the players before turning the dragon against the party.

After each attack, Lennithon swoops away until his breath weapon recharges, then swings in for another attack. He repeats this pattern until it has taken 24 damage or more, or a single critical hit. After that happens, Lennithon leaves for good.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Characters earn 50 XP each for driving away Lennithon, but reduce that award to 25 XP if 10 or more defenders were killed during the attack. For their role in driving off the dragon, the characters receive four {@item Potion of Healing||potions of healing} from the grateful Governor Nighthill.

entries.name: Prisoners
entries: Governor Nighthill would like to interrogate some of the raiders.
"I'd give anything to know what we're up against, and why. For that, we need prisoners. A commander, even a low-ranking one, is best."

If the characters haven't run into any cult leaders yet, Nighthill takes them onto the parapet and points out what he means. This is an ideal time for everyone to catch a glimpse of {@creature Frulam Mondath|HotDQ} (see {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}) in her purple robes, accompanied by a dozen guards. Even the governor cautions characters against attacking such a formidable force, especially when any lower-level officer can answer his questions.

Leaving the keep through the front gate is out of the question—too many raiders watch it, and they would jump the characters as soon as they moved away from the keep. Other options are waiting for a cloud to cover the moon before climbing down ropes tossed over the back wall of the keep, or using the old tunnel that exits into the stream bed.

This mission can be combined with another mission, such as saving the mill or rescuing villagers from the temple of Chauntea (area 3). All characters need to do is bring a live cultist or Cult of the Dragon initiate back to the keep. Or characters can go into the town hunting for one specifically.
Prisoners brought back to the keep are interrogated by Governor Nighthill and a few of his picked guards. Characters can participate if they want to.

items: Captured kobolds are terrified; they say whatever they think the questioner wants to hear. They know that they're working for the Cult of the Dragon and for the "dragon lady" ({@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}), and that they're after loot.

Captured mercenaries or bandits talk freely; they have no special loyalty to the Cult of the Dragon. They reveal that they've been raiding communities around the Greenfields for loot, and they've heard rumors in the camp about dragon eggs.

Cultists and initiates are the most tight-lipped. A successful DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) or DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check is needed to cause cultists to reveal that they are members of the Cult of the Dragon and that they are collecting loot "for the great hoard that will usher in the reign of the Queen of Dragons." They know that the cult has a clutch of dragon eggs under heavy guard in a cave at the camp.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: If characters capture a prisoner, award each of them 25 XP. To collect that award, the prisoner must be brought to the governor. Interrogating the prisoner independently and bringing the information to the governor doesn't count. The characters also receive standard XP for any monsters they defeat along the way.

entries.name: Save the Mill
entries: From the parapet of the keep, someone spots a group of raiders trying to set fire to the town mill (area 4). Governor Nighthill quickly approaches the adventurers.

"The guards have spotted a new threat. Raiders are trying to set fire to the town's mill. If it burns, we'll lose our stockpile of flour and we won't be able to grind more for months. I'm trying to assemble enough defenders from here in the keep to defend it through the rest of the night, but that will take time. You'd do us a great service if you could get to the mill quickly and drive away the raiders before they can set it aflame. You'll need to defend it until our force arrives to take over, but it shouldn't be more than fifteen minutes behind you."
The mill is about 500 feet from the keep. The distance is doubled if characters use the secret tunnel and follow the stream to stay hidden.

Roll a {@dice d6} on the {@area Chapter 1 Encounters|06e|x} table to determine the strength of the raiders that are trying to set fire to the mill. Any kobolds in this force run away as soon as two or more raiders are killed. If characters observe the mill for a minute or more before attacking, allow them to attempt DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) or Charisma ({@skill Performance}) checks. If successful, a character realizes that the raiders are making a demonstration of starting a fire, but it's for show. A few fires are burning around the building, but they could be extinguished easily.

This act of burning the mill is a ruse. Mondath has been informed that heroes are aiding the town, and she wants to lure them into an ambush. More raiders—one {@creature cultist} and one {@creature guard} per character—are hiding inside the mill, waiting for the characters to show up.

The mill is a simple rectangular barn, about 40 feet long and 20 feet wide, with an attached, exterior office. The long side of the building away from the stream has barn doors and a two-part door, and the two short walls have windows. All these openings are closed, but none are locked or barred. Inside, the main floor is dominated by a massive stone grinding wheel driven by a water wheel in the stream. The mill was operating late when the raid began and the millers fled without disengaging the wheel, so it still turns noisily. The upper half of the barn is a loft where milled flour is stored. The loft can be reached by wooden stairs along the east wall or by using the ropes and pulleys that hoist bags of flour up and down through large openings in the loft floor.

The ambushers are waiting in the loft for heroes to enter the mill. When the heroes are inside, the guards launch a volley of spears from above, then leap down to fight hand-to-hand. The ambushers have a good chance to gain a surprise round for their spear volley; a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check is needed to notice them before the attack. Characters who scan the loft for hidden enemies upon entering the mill have advantage on the check.

Ten minutes after the second fight ends, a dozen bloody but basically healthy defenders arrive from the keep with orders to relieve the characters and defend the mill. They tell the characters to go back to the keep quietly while they remain behind at the mill.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Award standard XP for defeated foes. If characters realized they were walking into a trap, give each a 50 XP bonus. If they didn't deduce that it was a trap but spotted the ambushers in time to prevent a surprise round, give each character a 25 XP bonus.

entries.name: Sanctuary
entries: Dozens of townsfolk have barricaded themselves inside the temple to Chauntea (area 3), which is surrounded by raiders. The attackers tried setting fire to the stout structure but had little success. Now they've deployed an improvised battering ram. It's only a matter of time, possibly minutes, before the temple's main doors crumple under the assault, leaving the people inside helpless.

The temple is a large building, made of fieldstone with a peaked slate roof, and square in shape. It is taller than most other buildings in town. Inside, the altar occupies the middle of the temple, with other worship areas arranged around it.

entries.name: Foes
entries: The force outside the temple is split into three groups. One (A) is battering at the front doors, another (B) is circling the temple in a screeching mob, and the third (C) is heaping burning straw against a rear door. All these groups together would overwhelm 1st-level characters, but characters can devise a plan that gets them inside the temple by dealing with one group.

Group A consists of one {@creature dragonclaw|HotDQ} (see {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}), two {@creature Cultist||cultists}, and six {@creature Kobold||kobolds}. The cultists are handling the ram while the kobolds stand guard in case the town militia mounts a counterattack. The dragonclaw is in charge. The kobold guards are alert, but they are distracted when Group B passes in front of the temple.

Group B consists of three {@creature Cultist||cultists}, ten {@creature Kobold||kobolds}, and two {@creature Ambush Drake|HotDQ|ambush drakes} (see {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}) strung out in a mob that stretches 50 feet. This procession with leaping and whirling kobolds completes one circuit around the temple approximately every eight minutes (two minutes per side).

Group C consists of four {@creature Cultist||cultists} and four {@creature Kobold||kobolds} clustered tightly around the temple's back door. Their meager fire produces little flame, instead creating prodigious clouds of thick smoke that engulf the back of the temple and blanket the surrounding 30 feet of ground. Everything in the smoke is lightly obscured, and objects or creatures that are seen through more than 15 feet of smoke are heavily obscured. Characters can sneak up on these raiders and gain a surprise round against them, as long as they avoid Group B in the process.

entries.name: Arranging a Rescue
entries: The heroes' best shot at rescuing the townsfolk is to overpower Group C and take control of the back door. In the temple, they can arrange a distraction to keep Groups A and B occupied at the front while the citizens of Greenest slip out the back and race for the keep or for the old tunnel—if characters have opened it already. That's only one possibility; clever players can come up with different solutions.

The townsfolk in the temple are near panic, however, and they won't take orders from strangers unless someone makes a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. Otherwise, characters need to locate the priest of Chauntea, Eadyan Falconmoon, a level-headed half-elf. He's easy to spot, being the only calm person they can find in the temple, and he is elated to see them. He looks to the characters for a plan.

Time is pressing. While characters are inside the temple, remind them of the booming blows of the battering ram against the front doors and the frightened townsfolk. How much time you allow before the doors burst open depends on your group. What's important is that players feel pressed. To create a sense of pressure, give the front doors 30 hit points and let each thud of the battering ram deal {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning damage. When the doors reach 20 hit points, they have cracks large enough to see through. At 10 hit points, the doors sag in their hinges. At 5, they could collapse at the next impact. How frequently you roll the die is up to you! One roll every 15–20 seconds is a good target for an average group. Be flexible, judge the players' level of tension, and don't let anyone relax.

If the doors burst open before the temple is evacuated, this scene turns into an ugly melee against Group A. The kobolds in that group prefer to attack unarmed villagers instead of lethal adventurers. Each kobold automatically kills one villager each round unless characters attack the kobolds, cut them off from their victims, or interfere some other way. If townsfolk have already evacuated the temple through the back door, or that process is well along before the front doors split apart under the ram, then characters can conduct a fighting withdrawal through the temple. After everyone gets into the smoke outside, they can close and brace the back door, then sprint for the keep or the tunnel in the stream bank with enough of a head start to get away safely.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Rescuing people from the temple earns each character 100 XP in addition to the points for killing monsters. If more than ten villagers died during the rescue, reduce that award to 50 XP.

entries.name: Half-Dragon Champion
entries: Before all the raiders depart, their champion challenges the town's best warrior.

From the darkness, a creature strides into the dim light of the dying fires around the keep. Although it is shaped roughly like a human, it is at least seven feet tall, its skin is covered in blue scales, its fingers bear wicked claws, and its face has the muzzle and reptilian eyes of a dragon. The creature stops about eighty yards from the main gate of the keep and scans the walls. A line of kobolds fans out behind it. With their spears, they prod four human prisoners into the dim light. You can make out a woman, a teenage boy in a blood-soaked tunic, and two children. Then the half-dragon creature hails the keep.

"Defenders of Greenest! This has been a successful night, and I am feeling generous. Do you see these four pitiful, useless prisoners? We have no need for them, so I will trade them back to you. Send out your best warrior to fight me, and you can have these four in exchange."

The speaker is {@creature Langdedrosa Cyanwrath|HotDQ} (see {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12} for statistics) a half-blue dragon who serves the Cult of the Dragon. Cyanwrath has a personal troop of sixteen {@creature Kobold||kobolds}. A character who makes a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) or Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check recognizes the creature as a half-dragon from descriptions.

One of the defenders in the keep, Sergeant Markguth, recognizes the prisoners as his sister and her children, and he is ready to rush out into battle with the half-dragon. Escobert the Red and a few other defenders restrain him while Nighthill approaches the characters.

"My friends, you've demonstrated your prowess all through this frightful night. I realize this is an awful burden to ask you to bear, but any of you has a better chance to defeat that horror than my militia have."

If no one steps forward, Nighthill is disappointed but says he understands, and their refusal in no way diminishes what they've done so far. In that case, the woman's brother goes out to face the half-dragon. He is a human {@creature guard}. Select one of the players to control Sergeant Markguth for this fight or just narrate its result.

Cyanwrath is pleased to see a champion step forward. He agrees to these terms for the combat: The three children will be set loose immediately, but his kobolds will continue to stand guard over the woman, and they will kill her if anyone interferes in the fight—for example, if archers in the keep let fly at him. Regardless of who wins, the woman will be released when the fight is over; and the victor will be the last one standing.

Governor Nighthill holds his troops in the keep during the combat. Adventurers can go out if they want, but the half-dragon insists that they keep their distance and stay between him and the fortress. If characters try to surround him or to edge into position for an ambush, he warns them that his kobolds won't hesitate to kill the hostages if they see signs of treachery. The half-dragon is evil, but he has a deep sense of honor about one-on-one combat. He doesn't intend any shenanigans, and he won't allow any from his kobolds.

Cyanwrath is the likely winner of this match, whether he's fighting Sergeant Markguth or a character. When his foe drops, he strikes one more time; the last blow kills Markguth or inflicts one death roll failure on a character. If Cyanwrath loses the fight, the kobolds immediately jump in to protect his body and carry it away. (Cyanwrath will recover from his wounds and be encountered again later.) If by some mischance Cyanwrath is killed or captured, his place in the dragon hatchery ({@adventure chapter 3|HotDQ|3}) is taken by another half-dragon.
With the fight over, the last of the raiders retreat en masse from the town into the darkness, marching away toward the southeast.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: If a character steps up to the challenge and fights Cyanwrath, each party member earns 50 XP. If not, characters receive nothing for this encounter. A team of healers with healer's kits and +4 bonuses to Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) checks attend to the wounded or dying character, and Governor Nighthill gratefully offers two {@item Potion of Healing||potions of healing} to the wounded character. If characters do something that costs the life of a hostage, Governor Nighthill is furious with them and offers no more help.

entries.name: Developments
entries: It's assumed that when characters first see the fighting in Greenest, they will rush to its defense. If they don't, and they're traveling with others, then the NPCs they're traveling with suggest that an immediate attack might turn the tide or at least save many lives. If characters still sit out this fight, they see about half of the attackers leave around midnight, with the rest retiring in small groups over the next few hours. When the sun comes up, even a quick inspection shows that over half of the buildings are heavily damaged and much of the town's wealth was carried away. Hundreds of injured people are crowded into the keep or are found hiding in cellars, but most of them will survive.

data.name: Chapter 2: Raiders' Camp
entries: In the warm light of day, Governor Nighthill and other leaders want to know who was behind the attack on Greenest, and why the town was a target. The raiders retreated toward the southeast, and their trail is easy to spot. A small, stealthy group could follow the trail to the raiders' camp and gather information.

Governor Nighthill approaches the characters with a proposal: If they locate the raiders' camp and find out certain information, he offers to pay them 250 gp apiece. He wants to know where the camp is sited, how many raiders are there, who their leaders are, what's motivating these attacks, and where they plan to strike next. If characters recover valuables that were stolen from the town, he would like them returned, but he does his best to arrange a reward from what's left of the town treasury. Recovering treasure, however, is a lesser goal when compared to the other objectives he brings up.

Any gear or supplies the characters need for the trip are furnished by the town. As characters prepare to set off on this mission (or to leave town if they turn down the mission), though, an injured monk approaches.

A young man walks up to you, limping heavily on his bandaged left leg. "I hear that you intend to follow the raiders and see where they've gone. I'd like nothing better than to come with you, but in this condition, I'd slow you down. In the midst of all this tragedy, there's no reason you would have heard about the fate of my master, {@creature Leosin Erlanthar|HotDQ}, but it's important you know. He is a monk from Berdusk. He disappeared last night, after we fought a particularly savage battle against raiders. A few others and I fought our way to the keep, barely. Leosin didn't make it at all. We went back this morning to look for him, but all we found was his broken staff and this choker, which he always wore."
The monk's name is Nesim Waladra. After introductions are made, he continues.

"Leosin has been investigating these raiders for months. I fear that he might have tried to infiltrate their group when they retreated, or worse, was captured and carried away as a prisoner. No one understands these bandits better than he does, and his knowledge will be invaluable against them. When you find their camp, please look for any sign that Leosin is there. One of my brothers has already departed for Berdusk to bring back help, but it will be many days before help arrives. Anything you can do before then would be a godsend."

Nesim answers the characters' questions to the best of his ability, but he also urges them to move quickly. The monks were returning to Berdusk from the great library at Candlekeep, where Leosin was consulting the librarians and researching ancient writings on dragon folklore. Dragon cults are his special interest.
The broken staff is nothing special. The choker is a braided leather neckband with a silver dragon design chased into the leather. The ends are ragged, as if it was roughly torn off.

entries.name: Tracking the Raiders
entries: The raiders' path is easy to follow across the rolling grassland of the Greenfields. A wide swath of grass is trampled down, but it's impossible to determine the raiders' numbers precisely. The path only confirms what characters already know: there were a lot of them, and they were a mix of humans, kobolds, and trained reptiles. One bit of information can be gleaned with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check: Many of the beasts' footprints are deeper on the retreat than they were on the approach march. They were weighed down with loot on the homeward-bound trip, but let players reach that conclusion on their own. It's not possible to tell from the confusing jumble of prints whether any specific footprints are those of prisoners.

The trail leads south about twelve miles, to a more rugged region where steep-sided, rocky plateaus replace the gently rolling hills. The land between the plateaus is largely flat, broken only by outcroppings and wandering streams in steep-sided gullies. The plateaus jut fifty to one hundred feet above their surroundings and are difficult to climb except where rock falls and subsidence created natural ramps. The crumbling sides of the plateaus are dotted with caves and tumbled boulder fields.

Characters can have two encounters during this trip. The first is with a group of raiders who have straggled behind the main body. They are disorganized and quarrelsome, and they should be easy prey for alert adventurers. The second group is an organized rearguard watching specifically for pursuers from the town. They present a much graver threat.

entries.name: Cult of the Dragon Ranks
entries: The Cult of the Dragon has an active recruiting process, accepting initiates from a young age. An initiate (use the {@creature cultist} stat block) trains for months or years before gaining any rank within the organization, and many trainees don't survive the tests. An initiate who passes the tests must choose an affinity to a particular color of dragon: black, blue, green, red, or white. He or she is then welcomed into the ranks as a dragonclaw.

The higher ranks of the cult, in ascending order, are dragonclaw, dragonwing, dragonfang, dragonsoul, and wyrmspeaker. There are only five wyrmspeakers, one per color of chromatic dragon. The current wyrmspeakers are Severin (red), Galvan (blue), Neronvain (green), {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} (black), and Varram (white).

Most of the cult's operations are overseen by local leaders called Wearers of Purple for the ceremonial robes that they wear. All of the wyrmspeakers are Wearers of Purple, as are lower-ranking cultists appointed by the wyrmspeakers to preside over cult enclaves.

entries.name: Stragglers
entries: Characters spot this group's cooking fire smoke from several miles away, because the stragglers stopped to roast a few prairie hens for a meal. They sought shelter in a low spot between surrounding hills, where tall boulders have rolled into a loose jumble. In fact, the surroundings offer no protection while making it easier for enemies to sneak up on the site.

By observing for a few minutes, characters can discern that there are four human {@creature Cultist||cultists} and eight {@creature Kobold||kobolds} in the group. The kobolds and humans distrust each other, and although the cultists act as if they're the bosses, their leadership amounts to nothing more than ineffectual bullying. The humans' weapons are stacked against a rock, out of easy reach. The kobolds have their weapons on their belts.

If the group is left alone, the kobolds grab their share of the half-cooked lunch and move about fifty yards away to eat, while the humans continue squabbling over how to cook a hen and the uselessness of kobolds as allies.
If characters choose to bypass this group, a detour can get them around it with no difficulty. They could run into these stragglers again on their way back to Greenest.

If characters attack, then unless they give away their presence on purpose (by hailing the camp, for example), they gain a surprise round. The humans spend their first turns retrieving their weapons and shields. The kobolds drop their food and scatter, then regroup and counterattack on round four, using their slings as much as possible. They stick around and fight only as long as any of their human allies are still fighting. As soon as the humans are all defeated, the remaining kobolds slink away into the hills and aren't seen again.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Award standard XP for defeated foes, including kobolds that ran away. If any cultists are questioned, they refuse to talk unless someone succeeds at a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check. They know it's standard practice for a raiding party to leave behind a rearguard. They don't know how strong the rearguard will be, but they expect it is sited about a mile ahead where the path passes between rocky bluffs. They also can describe the raiders' camp and its location, plus they know some prisoners were taken from the town but not how many or whether they include a half-elf monk. They know the raid was for loot, because they were told to look specifically for gold, gems, and other valuables and were forbidden to do any looting for themselves. Cultists know they are preparing "the great hoard to honor the Dragon Queen."

Captured kobolds talk freely, but most of what they say is lies. That's not because they try to mislead enemies, but because they will say anything, no matter how outlandish, if it might gain them their freedom.

The cultists have 28 sp among them, besides their cheap weapons. The kobolds, who looted despite their orders, have a sack containing pewter candlesticks, some silver serving dishes, and a few religious carvings of Chauntea taken from a home shrine.

entries.name: Rearguard
entries: If the characters learn of the camp location and probable site of the rearguard from the stragglers, they can use that information to bypass this encounter entirely. In fact, that would be the smart thing to do, both because it negates a damaging fight and because if the rearguard is wiped out, leaders in the cult will wonder why it never reported back. The best result for the characters is if the outpost checks in at the correct time with an "all clear."

The rearguard consists of one {@creature veteran}, six {@creature Cultist||cultists}, and two {@creature Acolyte||acolytes}. The guard and cultists have spears for both ranged and melee combat. They are positioned in an area where the trail winds through a gap between two outcrops. The ambushers are hidden in the rocks, 12 to 15 feet above ground level. Characters might detect the ambush, with the odds depending on what they know and how they approach the area.

items: If stragglers described the likely ambush spot to characters, it can be recognized from 200 yards away with a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.
If stragglers mentioned the rearguard but didn't describe the spot, it is recognized as a good spot for an ambush from 100 yards away with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

If characters haven't been warned about the rearguard, someone spots a face peering down from above with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, but not until the characters are within 20 yards.
If players state that they're watching for potential ambush spots, give them advantage when making these checks.

entries: The rearguard has a twofold mission. It must stop any small party of intruders coming up the trail, or harass and delay a larger group while sending word to the camp that trouble approaches. The veteran decides that he has enough of an advantage against a party of five or six adventurers to deal with the problem on the spot, provided he doesn't weaken his force by sending a runner to {@creature Frulam Mondath|HotDQ}. If the adventuring group contains seven or more characters, you can either have the veteran harass the enemy and dispatch a runner to the camp, or you can add cultists until they outnumber the characters by two or three, then let the cultists make a stand.

If characters walk into the trap, the cultists tumble boulders onto them. Each character must succeed on a DC 11 Dexterity saving throw or take {@dice 2d12} bludgeoning damage from falling rocks (half as much damage on a successful save). The boulder attack constitutes the cultists' surprise round. After that, they use ranged attacks until they are out of ammunition or the heroes force them into melee. Because they are positioned in the rocks above the characters, the cultists have three-quarters cover against attacks from below (+5 bonus to AC). To reach the foes, characters must scramble up the rocks. The distance is only 10 to 15 feet and no ability check is required, but the rocks are {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Developments
entries: These raiders are distinctly different from the earlier stragglers. All are dressed in similar (but not identical) black leather tunics with flared, black mantles. These are dedicated cultists. If captured, nothing less than a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check can pry any information from them. Even with that, all they reveal is that they are initiates in the Cult of the Dragon, the names of their leaders ({@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}, {@creature Frulam Mondath|HotDQ}, and {@creature Langdedrosa Cyanwrath|HotDQ}), and that the raid on Greenest was to collect treasure for dragons. {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} outranks the other leaders.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Award standard XP for defeated foes. The cultists have no treasure, but their Cult of the Dragon outfits and weapons could be invaluable when characters try to get into the raiders' camp.

entries.name: The Camp
entries: The cultists have set up their camp in the hollow of a rocky plateau that's shaped roughly like a horseshoe. The lower portion of the plateau rises gently from the surrounding land, but it quickly steepens and ascends to a height of 150 feet above the landscape. Boulders form jumbled heaps at the bases of the cliffs. The level shelves and top of the plateau are covered in long grass, and brush and scrubby trees grow in patches.

entries.name: Boulders
entries: The boulders are {@quickref difficult terrain||3} and provide three-quarters cover.

entries.name: Brush
entries: The brush around the site grows to a height of 4 to 6 feet. It is tough and dense, making it {@quickref difficult terrain||3} and providing three-quarters cover to targets sheltering among it.

entries.name: Caves
entries: The steep sides of the plateau are dotted with shallow caves. Boulders or brush conveniently conceals many of the cave mouths. Characters who need to take a long rest can easily find a secure cave in which to hide.

entries.name: Guard Towers
entries: The cultists have built two guard towers at the camp, one at the entrance to the hollow and one atop the plateau. These towers are 20 feet high and made from rough timbers lashed together with rope. They are large enough for a few lookouts. The tower at the mouth of the hollow is manned by kobolds, while warriors man the one above. The guards have horns to blow when they must sound an alarm.

entries.name: Prisoners
entries: The cultists' prisoners are kept at area 1. Currently, only eight prisoners are in the camp, not counting Leosin. During the day, they are put to work under guard by four {@creature Dragonclaw|HotDQ|dragonclaws} (see {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}). At night, they are shackled to a post in their hut to prevent escape. The shackles are secured by a single chain and lock that can be opened with a key carried by one of the guards or with thieves' tools and a successful DC 10 Dexterity check. The chain can be broken with a successful DC 20 Strength check. Five of the prisoners are from Greenest, and the other three are from earlier raids against hamlets and small farming villages to the south and east. There were more prisoners at one time, but many have died from overwork and mistreatment. If a situation develops where released prisoners must fight, use {@creature commoner} stats for them.

entries.name: Slopes
entries: The sides of the plateau rise sharply, while the floor of the hollow slopes up gradually toward the east. A long ladder is lashed to the cliff so guards can reach the upper guard tower.

The cliffs have handholds and footholds for climbing, so no die roll is needed under normal circumstances. If characters are in a hurry, a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check is needed to make the climb without falling. If characters are concerned about keeping quiet, then a successful DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check ensures that no rocks break loose and rattle down.

entries.name: Tents
entries: The raiders live in circular huts made from closely spaced wooden or bone poles covered in hide, mud, and sod. Huts vary in diameter from 10 feet to 25 feet, and in height from 5 feet to 10 feet. (Symbols on the map represent clusters of tents.) Those in the mouth of the hollow (level 1 on the map) are crudely built and decorated with animal skulls. These are occupied by kobolds. Cultists occupy the huts on level 2, which are sturdier, cleaner, and decorated with painted designs representing dragons. A few tents on level 2 are set aside for prisoners.

The large tent at area 2 is set apart from the others by an open space. It is reserved for {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}, {@creature Frulam Mondath|HotDQ}, {@creature Langdedrosa Cyanwrath|HotDQ}, and {@creature Azbara Jos|HotDQ}. An honor guard of four {@creature Veteran||veterans} and four {@creature Guard Drake|HotDQ|guard drakes} ({@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}) keeps watch around this tent day and night. They don't sleep at their posts, they don't fall for tricks, and they don't listen to stories or pleas. Their job is to keep everyone away from the tent, and they are fanatical about it. Only acolytes and adepts the veterans know by sight and by voice are allowed to approach.

entries.name: Camp Alertness
entries: For the first day following the raid, the cultists are both elated with the outcome and exhausted. {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} doesn't expect a serious challenge from the town, and slower members of the raiding party and walking wounded straggle into camp all through the day after the raid. The situation at the camp is confused and security is lax. Most of these raiders are mercenaries and bandits, and not even the dedicated cultists wear recognizable uniforms on raids. No one challenges latecomers for passwords or security signals. Put simply, the raiders are confident that no enemies followed them this far. Characters can walk straight into the camp without having their identities seriously challenged. In fact, the bolder they are, the more likely they are to blend right in.

Players may be tempted to have characters seek cover and observe during the day and not attempt to enter the camp until nightfall. This can work, too, but sneaking around in the dark is more likely to attract suspicion than simply walking in as if they belong in the camp.

The chief risk is that someone might recognize the characters from the fighting at Greenest. Have each character make a DC 5 Charisma check. Success means no one remembers the character's face, but failure means that at some time (not necessarily immediately, but when recognition would be the most dramatic), someone in the camp recognizes the character. If characters are wearing Cult of the Dragon regalia taken from the rearguard, the characters have disadvantage on this roll because no one returning to camp at this time should be in uniform. The character who faced Cyanwrath one-on-one, however, has a -4 penalty to the roll. If that character ever comes face-to-face with the half-dragon, recognition is automatic.

As the day wears on and the commotion winds down, the camp becomes calmer and better organized. Guards resume their normal routines. If characters haven't entered the camp before sundown of the first day, they find it more difficult, since there's very little traffic in and out of the camp on a normal day. They'll need a good story and a successful DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check to walk past a guard station of five {@creature Guard||guards}. This check can be made only once for the group; they can't talk their way out of a failure. After the initial opportunity to enter the camp has passed, characters need to resort to stealth or subterfuge to get in. For example, characters scaling the plateau from the east could use brush for cover right up to where the cliff overlooks the camp. From there, they could observe or climb down the rocks under cover of darkness.

The whole camp goes on alert if the bodies of murdered human sentries or cultists are discovered. One dead kobold won't cause much alarm, but many dead kobolds will. If the camp goes on alert, every character must make a DC 15 Charisma check. A failure means the character has been spotted as a stranger and an infiltrator. Someone raises the hue and cry, which quickly draws a crowd. A roll of 10 or lower means someone has recognized the character from the fight in Greenest. The characters have a chance to get away if they immediately go on the attack and begin cutting their way out of camp, but if they delay or spin tales, a crowd of {@creature Cultist||cultists} that outnumbers them five to one surrounds them.

If characters try to estimate numbers in the camp, they count roughly one hundred kobolds and a mix of bandits, guards, and cultists totaling about eighty—effectively an unlimited supply if characters get the idea of fighting them all.

entries.name: Captured!
entries: If caught, characters are disarmed, their hands are tied, and they are brought before {@creature Frulam Mondath|HotDQ} for judgment. One by one, she asks them who they are, where they came from, and what they're doing in her camp.

items: If anyone was recognized from the fighting in Greenest, it doesn't matter what the characters say. Mondath sentences all of them to be executed on the morrow, after spending the night tied to posts alongside the monk Leosin. Characters have one night to escape this fate. They might wriggle out of their bonds, bribe or charm a cultist to set them free, or come up with a clever use for a cantrip. If all else fails, Leosin reveals that he has a hidden knife with which they can cut themselves free.
If characters admit they came from Greenest and are enemies of the cult, the effect is the same as if they'd been recognized.

If characters lie to Mondath—claiming they are new recruits and this is all a mistake, for example, or that they are studying the cult before deciding whether to join—then compare their Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks to Mondath's Wisdom check to determine whether she believes them. You can allow advantage or disadvantage on the roll when someone's lies are especially plausible or implausible. Match die rolls individually for every character. Those who Mondath believes are set free, but watched and stopped if they try to leave the camp. Those who Mondath does not believe are sentenced to die as above.

entries.name: Exploring the Camp
entries: Characters can learn much from poking around in the camp. If the characters pose as cult members, they can speak to other cultists and question them (carefully) about the cult's plans and long-term goals. Most cultists should be treated as indifferent when determining reactions or trying to gain a favor. Kobolds are less helpful and should be considered hostile when characters make Charisma checks to gauge their reaction.

Characters can learn the following information through observation and questioning. They need to be careful, however, not to attract attention for asking too many questions or poking their noses into things that are none of their business. Any time they come off as "too nosy," feel free to call for another Charisma check to see whether someone recognizes them from Greenest.

items: This is a camp of the Cult of the Dragon—praise Tiamat's glory!

Not everyone here is a full-fledged member of the cult. Many are new initiates working toward full acceptance, and many others are simple mercenaries, hired to flesh out the camp's strength during raids or if it should come under attack.

The kobolds are here because their worshipful attitude toward dragons makes them easy for {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} and other high-ranking cultists to manipulate, but they are not well liked or trusted by the other races.
Hunters who bring in antelope and other large game from the grasslands feed the camp. The cultists and their allies eat most of it, but some is stored in the cave to feed the hatchlings.

The cult has been ranging far and wide on small raids to collect treasure. Greenest was the closest target to the camp, the biggest of all the towns they've attacked, and the most profitable—praise Tiamat's glory!

Prisoners are used for manual labor. In the past, a few have "converted" and become loyal members of the cult, but most die eventually of overwork and undernourishment. Then they are fed to the drakes or taken into the cave to feed the hatchlings.

The cave at the back of the camp (area 4) is off-limits to all but those who've been cleared by Mondath and {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}, which includes a handful of guards and kobolds. It's known around camp as "the nursery," and it's an open secret that {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} plans to hatch a clutch of dragon eggs there.
The half-black dragon {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} came to the area a few months ago, and she set up the camp. Mondath handles everyday operations.
The half-blue dragon Cyanwrath is Mondath's right hand and is seldom far from her side. He has a rigid sense of honor, but you don't want to make him angry.
The mother of dragons—praise Tiamat's glory—shall return, and when that day comes, all the nations of the world shall tremble before her majesty!

The monk is of special interest to {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}. Why else would she keep the creature alive that way? What {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} hopes to learn from him is anyone's guess, but you wouldn't want to be in that half-elf's skin—or what's left of it—when the questioning gets serious.
The plunder from nearby settlements is stored in the cave. No one but {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} knows how much is there altogether, but it must be a big pile by now.

entries: Aside from being recognized, the chief risk of spending time in the cultist camp is getting roped into a work detail. Characters might be selected by an officer to spend a few hours helping with food preparation, standing guard in a tower, practicing weapon drill, or even cleaning up after animals (a job usually reserved for prisoners, but currently the number of prisoners in the camp is low).

entries.name: Leosin Erlanthar
entries: The monk is tied to a stake at the back of the camp (area 3). He has been severely beaten, and he has been denied food and water in an effort to break his spirit. {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} knows from informants across the Sword Coast that Leosin has been researching the cult's history and recent activity. The wyrmspeaker wants to know how much Leosin has learned and with whom he shared his information. {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} considered it an amazing stroke of luck that Leosin was captured during the raid.

In fact, it wasn't luck at all, at least not for {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}. Leosin had studied their previous attacks and concluded that the time was right for the cult to strike a bigger target, and he knew that Greenest was prosperous yet poorly defended, making it the most likely next target. So, when he deemed the time was just about right, he visited the town with the intent of staying until something happened. His observations paid off, and Leosin separated from his people during the night and fell in with the raiders when they retreated, hoping to learn more about the cult's plans and the location of their camp. {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} spotted him after the sun came up, and the monk was quickly overpowered and captured.

That portion of Leosin's scheme has worked reasonably well. He now knows most of the information listed above under "Exploring the Camp." Unfortunately for him, captivity has been more brutal than he expected, and although his mind and will are still strong, he's in a very poor physical state.

Despite the danger, Leosin isn't entirely happy about being rescued if characters come to set him free. He believes he can learn more, and he's willing to take the risk. He's too weak to resist, however, so characters can easily take him away against his will if that's what they want to do. He can move without aid at a speed of 20 feet and fights as a commoner with disadvantage on attack rolls. If characters don't bring him out of the camp, Leosin breaks away on his own. He refuses to talk about it later.

If characters are captured and imprisoned alongside Leosin and their attempts to escape fall through, he reveals that he has a small knife hidden in his boot. They can use it to cut their bonds. Leosin's absence is noticed within five minutes if he is taken away, and an alarm goes up throughout the camp. Rigging up a dummy in his place delays the discovery by twenty minutes. Tying up a dead or {@condition unconscious} cultist (preferably a half-elf) in his place assures the intruders a two-hour head start before the escape is noticed.

entries.name: Rewards
entries: Award standard XP for defeated foes. This chapter does not involve many fights, but it does present many challenges, and characters should be rewarded for overcoming them. The awards listed below are just recommendations; adjust them and add to them as you see fit. Characters can reach 3rd level if they act prudently and capitalize on all the opportunities the camp offers, but it's not essential that they do.

items: If you are using the milestone experience rule, the characters reach 3rd level when they complete this chapter.
For getting into and out of the cultists' camp without causing an alarm or being caught: 100 XP per character.
For getting into and out of the cultists' camp without stirring any suspicion: an additional 100 XP per character.
For rescuing Leosin: 250 XP per character.
For leaving a dummy or decoy in Leosin's place: an additional 50 XP per character.
For rescuing other prisoners: 25 XP for each prisoner brought out of the camp alive.
For each piece of information listed under "Exploring the Camp" that characters learn on their own (not from Leosin): 25 XP per character.

entries: When the characters arrive safely back at Greenest—presumably with Leosin in tow—he can fill them in on any details they missed during their investigation of the cult's camp. The monks who accompanied him are delighted to see him alive, and the families of any other released prisoners are equally grateful for the return of their loved ones. Governor Nighthill pays the characters their promised 250 gp each and publicly praises their courage and daring.

data.name: Chapter 3: Dragon Hatchery
entries: After his experience in captivity, Leosin needs several days to recover. When he's healthy again, he intends to travel north to Elturel to convey what he's learned to {@creature Ontharr Frume|HotDQ}, a paladin of Torm who shares his concern over the Cult of the Dragon's recent surge in activity. He has a favor to ask of the characters.

"After all you've done already for me personally and for the people of Greenest, I hate to ask anything more from you. But the need is great, and I dare to hope that you can aid me one time more. I need you to return to the cultists' camp. You know your way around it now. If the cultists are preparing to conduct another raid, or a large body of them marches away, or if anything substantial is carried into or out of that cave, I need to know. If you have a chance to get into the camp and look around again, that would be the ideal way to spot anything that's changed.
"I don't recommend letting yourselves get captured," he adds with a wry smile.

If the characters were working as caravan guards, Leosin offers to match whatever their previous employer was paying them plus 20 percent. If they are currently unemployed, he offers them 150 gp apiece. He's willing to haggle; this mission is important, and no one else is available who Leosin believes can handle it. If the characters accept, he tells them to find him at the city of Elturel afterward, both to report and to collect their pay.
